content: S/L You are always railing on and on about NAFTA and "it's asian counterparts" as the source of this problem. The moving of jobs to China or where ever is problem and many jobs, more manufacturing jobs than others have moved out of the US due to these trade deals. BUT THAT IS NOT THE PROBLEM with the US owned IE "the Detroit three" They are being competed with by "foreign owned" companies with US subsidaries, like Chrysler is about to become. These compaines are more competitive because they pay less to begin with. They don't give free medical to employees and all there dependends "for life" They don't pay the differential of un-employment everytime a plant shuts down like Detrioit does. They don't allow guys that reach 30 years at age 48 or whatever to retire then, almost 20 years earlier than normal getting full pay and that free medical for life. They don't have thousands of non-working "job bank" guys sitting around doing nothing, a lot of them actually sit at home all while earning full pay, getting that free medical and logging time toward that 30 years and day retirement at 48. These are US subsidaries of foreign companies an idea that for the most part has always been supported by whoever is going to get the jobs. For example Mobile AL. is all for Airbus coming in to make planes. Nafta and the other trade agreements do not in any way control or have any influence of foreign companies setting up shop in the US. A US company opening a plant in China or where ever a German or Japanese company opening a plant in the US do not fall under the authority of NAFTA or the other trades deals. You mention tarriffs, again if it is made in the US that is a non starter. Transplants that are here IMO are here and nothing can be done to un-ring that bell. To keep from getting more some kind of Federal law, piece meal state to state would never get it done, it would have to be enacted that would not allow ANY foriegn comany from coming to the US not just a law for auto plants, everything no matter what it is, anything short of that would never stand a court challenge. Is the US ready to bar ALL foreign investment in the US? I highly doubt it.

content: S/L You are always railing on and on about NAFTA and "it's asian counterparts" as the source of this problem. The moving of jobs to China or where ever is problem and many jobs, more manufacturing jobs than others have moved out of the US due to these trade deals. BUT THAT IS NOT THE PROBLEM with the US owned IE "the Detroit three" They are being competed with by "foreign owned" companies with US subsidaries, like Chrysler is about to become. These compaines are more competitive because they pay less to begin with. They don't give free medical to employees and all there dependends "for life" They don't pay the differential of un-employment everytime a plant shuts down like Detrioit does. They don't allow guys that reach 30 years at age 48 or whatever to retire then, almost 20 years earlier than normal getting full pay and that free medical for life. They don't have thousands of non-working "job bank" guys sitting around doing nothing, a lot of them actually sit at home all while earning full pay, getting that free medical and logging time toward that 30 years and day retirement at 48. These are US subsidaries of foreign companies an idea that for the most part has always been supported by whoever is going to get the jobs. For example Mobile AL. is all for Airbus coming in to make planes. Nafta and the other trade agreements do not in any way control or have any influence of foreign companies setting up shop in the US. A US company opening a plant in China or where ever a German or Japanese company opening a plant in the US do not fall under the authority of NAFTA or the other trades deals. You mention tarriffs, again if it is made in the US that is a non starter. Transplants that are here IMO are here and nothing can be done to un-ring that bell. To keep from getting more some kind of Federal law, piece meal state to state would never get it done, it would have to be enacted that would not allow ANY foriegn comany from coming to the US not just a law for auto plants, everything no matter what it is, anything short of that would never stand a court challenge. Is the US ready to bar ALL foreign investment in the US? I highly doubt it.

content: "http://www.masslive.com/hampfrank/republican/index.ssf?/base/news-19/1241162246224680.xml&coll=1" WASHINGTON - President Barack Obama forced Chrysler into federal bankruptcy protection on Thursday so it could pursue a life-saving alliance with the Italian automaker Fiat, in yet another extraordinary intervention into private industry by the federal government. Flanked by his automobile task force of Cabinet secretaries and business advisers, Obama announced a plan that would allow the United Automobile Workers retirement plan to take control of Chrysler, with Fiat and the United States as junior partners. content: S/L You are always railing on and on about NAFTA and "it's asian counterparts" as the source of this problem. The moving of jobs to China or where ever is problem and many jobs, more manufacturing jobs than others have moved out of the US due to these trade deals. BUT THAT IS NOT THE PROBLEM with the US owned IE "the Detroit three" They are being competed with by "foreign owned" companies with US subsidaries, like Chrysler is about to become. These compaines are more competitive because they pay less to begin with. They don't give free medical to employees and all there dependends "for life" They don't pay the differential of un-employment everytime a plant shuts down like Detrioit does. They don't allow guys that reach 30 years at age 48 or whatever to retire then, almost 20 years earlier than normal getting full pay and that free medical for life. They don't have thousands of non-working "job bank" guys sitting around doing nothing, a lot of them actually sit at home all while earning full pay, getting that free medical and logging time toward that 30 years and day retirement at 48. These are US subsidaries of foreign companies an idea that for the most part has always been supported by whoever is going to get the jobs. For example Mobile AL. is all for Airbus coming in to make planes. Nafta and the other trade agreements do not in any way control or have any influence of foreign companies setting up shop in the US. A US company opening a plant in China or where ever a German or Japanese company opening a plant in the US do not fall under the authority of NAFTA or the other trades deals. You mention tarriffs, again if it is made in the US that is a non starter. Transplants that are here IMO are here and nothing can be done to un-ring that bell. To keep from getting more some kind of Federal law, piece meal state to state would never get it done, it would have to be enacted that would not allow ANY foriegn comany from coming to the US not just a law for auto plants, everything no matter what it is, anything short of that would never stand a court challenge. Is the US ready to bar ALL foreign investment in the US? I highly doubt it.

content: "http://www.masslive.com/hampfrank/republican/index.ssf?/base/news-19/1241162246224680.xml&coll=1" WASHINGTON - President Barack Obama forced Chrysler into federal bankruptcy protection on Thursday so it could pursue a life-saving alliance with the Italian automaker Fiat, in yet another extraordinary intervention into private industry by the federal government. Flanked by his automobile task force of Cabinet secretaries and business advisers, Obama announced a plan that would allow the United Automobile Workers retirement plan to take control of Chrysler, with Fiat and the United States as junior partners. The government would lend about $8 billion more to the company, on top of the $4 billion it had already provided. Your Tax Dollars at work You wanted change you got it

This is all just an exercise in futility, till we realize and correct the problem that go us into this mess in the first place... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

content: quote: Originally posted by ETCPJ: S/L You are always railing on and on about NAFTA and "it's asian counterparts" as the source of this problem. The moving of jobs to China or where ever is problem and many jobs, more manufacturing jobs than others have moved out of the US due to these trade deals. BUT THAT IS NOT THE PROBLEM with the US owned IE "the Detroit three" They are being competed with by "foreign owned" companies with US subsidaries, like Chrysler is about to become. These compaines are more competitive because they pay less to begin with. They don't give free medical to employees and all there dependends "for life" They don't pay the differential of un-employment everytime a plant shuts down like Detrioit does. They don't allow guys that reach 30 years at age 48 or whatever to retire then, almost 20 years earlier than normal getting full pay and that free medical for life. They don't have thousands of non-working "job bank" guys sitting around doing nothing, a lot of them actually sit at home all while earning full pay, getting that free medical and logging time toward that 30 years and day retirement at 48. These are US subsidaries of foreign companies an idea that for the most part has always been supported by whoever is going to get the jobs. For example Mobile AL. is all for Airbus coming in to make planes. Nafta and the other trade agreements do not in any way control or have any influence of foreign companies setting up shop in the US. A US company opening a plant in China or where ever a German or Japanese company opening a plant in the US do not fall under the authority of NAFTA or the other trades deals. You mention tarriffs, again if it is made in the US that is a non starter. Transplants that are here IMO are here and nothing can be done to un-ring that bell. To keep from getting more some kind of Federal law, piece meal state to state would never get it done, it would have to be enacted that would not allow ANY foriegn comany from coming to the US not just a law for auto plants, everything no matter what it is, anything short of that would never stand a court challenge. Is the US ready to bar ALL foreign investment in the US? I highly doubt it. It's called TARIFF, if it isn't made on American soil, with components manufactured on American soil, by American citizens, then slap TARIFFS on it!... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
